awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II: Smart Robotic Sanding Cells for Composite Parts in High-Mix Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

The broader impacts of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project seek to improve the quality of life for manufacturing workers, help U.S. manufacturers remain cost-competitive in the global market, and improve the quality of the manufactured parts. The proposed robotic cells may reduce the need for workers to perform ergonomically challenging sanding tasks and reduce the risk of worker injuries on sanding lines. The developed technologies will enable the human operators to focus on high-level decision making and the creative aspects of the manufacturing tasks, while the robotic assistants perform the low-level tedious tasks. Moreover, this technology enables the human operator to guide the team operation. This ability will improve worker productivity. Currently, there are more than 3000 companies in the U.S. performing composite fabrication. Most of these companies face challenges due to a shortage of workers and high labor churn. These challenges lead to longer delivery times. This project may  enable manufacturers to improve quality and lower costs. Moreover, the technology may enable manufacturers to reduce time to part delivery by reducing the reliance on human labor and easily scaling production capacity with the change in demand by adding or removing robotic cells.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project aims to develop a robotic sanding solution for high-mix applications by providing safety under uncertainty during robotic sanding and reducing cycle time by fast execution of safe and efficient trajectories by the robot. This award will make computational advances to enable robots to program themselves by automatically generating and safely executing trajectories based on the task description.  The project will also enable the computational algorithms to account for the uncertainties present in the environment, making robots useful for sanding operations in high-mix applications. A robotic sanding cell for handling large parts in high-mix applications will be developed by selecting the appropriate sensors and tools. Algorithms will be developed for fast and safe workpiece localization in the robotic cell while the workpiece is secured with a cost-effective, general-purpose, low-cost fixture. Algorithms will be developed to determine the minimum number of setups needed for sanding large parts in the robotic cell and to generate robot trajectories to produce tool motion patterns that ensure efficient and safe sanding operation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
​GrayMatter Robotics (GMR), a Los Angeles-based AI and robotics company, has significantly advanced the automation of surface finishing processes, particularly sanding for composites, with the support of the National Science Foundation (NSF) Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II award. This initiative has propelled technological innovation and yielded substantial societal, economic, and environmental benefits.​


Traditional sanding tasks are labor-intensive and expose workers to repetitive strain injuries, hazardous dust, and noise pollution. The AI-powered robotic sanding solution developed through this SBIR Phase II effort alleviates these risks by automating the sanding processes in high-mix manufacturing, thereby reducing workers' exposure to harmful conditions. The developed technology has been shown to reduce ergonomically challenging tasks by 90% across multiple manufacturing facilities, allowing workers to engage in higher value-added tasks and move away from the hazardous roles within the manufacturing sector. This leads to the creation of more jobs in manufacturing for a wide range of talent pool.


This effort demonstrated that the integration of AI and robotics into sanding operations led to increased efficiency and consistency in manufacturing processes. The developed solution enables manufacturers to achieve higher throughput with improved quality control. Specifically, the robotic systems were proven to operate 2 to 4 times faster than manual methods across multiple manufacturers. This technological advancement supports the revitalization of domestic manufacturing by making it more agile and responsive to market demands.​


The deployment of advanced robotic systems has spurred economic growth by creating new job opportunities in robotics maintenance, programming, and system integration. GMR's training programs enable workers to become robot operators in just a few days, facilitating workforce development and opening pathways for higher-paying, technology-oriented careers. 


This work exemplifies the successful translation of cutting-edge research into practical applications. The development of intelligent robotic systems for sanding tasks demonstrates the potential of AI to revolutionize traditional manufacturing processes. For instance, the solution developed in this effort can handle a variety of large & complex objects ranging from 1 to 12 meters in length with quick adjustment times, without the need for complex programming. This innovation serves as a model for integrating AI into various industrial applications, paving the way for further advancements in smart manufacturing.​


The automated sanding system developed in this effort contributes to environmental sustainability by optimizing material usage and reducing waste. The developed technology has been shown to reduce consumable waste by 30-70%, leading to a cleaner production environment. These improvements align with broader efforts to promote sustainable manufacturing practices.​


The developed solution has been proven to be applicable across a wide range of industries, including aerospace, defense, specialty vehicles (buses, trains, trucks, fire trucks, ambulances, delivery vans, and other utility & vocational vehicles), marine & boat building, and many general manufacturing industries. This work is critical for national security as it supports the manufacturing and sustainment operations for the US Department of Defense. 


The AI-powered sanding solution supported by the NSF SBIR Phase II award has significantly impacted the manufacturing industry by enhancing worker safety, increasing efficiency & productivity, fostering economic growth, national security, and promoting sustainability. This initiative exemplifies how targeted research and development can lead to transformative changes with wide-reaching benefits for society and the economy.
